Is that an optional test? If yes, please set continueOnError to true. And does T2 covers the test scope of current multi-asic T1?

@xwjiang-ms, No, this is intended to replace the mandatory t1-multi-asic PR checker, so it is set to be mandatory.

> Is that an optional test? If yes, please set continueOnError to true. And does T2 covers the test scope of current multi-asic T1?

@xwjiang-ms 
T2 PR checker may have some overlap coverage with T1-multi-asic because the LCs on KVM T2 are also multi-asic. Yet, there are additional T1 test cases running merely on T1-multi-asic, which are not covered by the KVM T2.

> @xwjiang-ms, No, this is intended to replace the mandatory t1-multi-asic PR checker, so it is set to be mandatory.
> 
> > Is that an optional test? If yes, please set continueOnError to true. And does T2 covers the test scope of current multi-asic T1?

OK, could you remove optional in the job name? We have some automation would filter out optional test jobs

I agree with removing the log. The test logic should just ensure that lldp is functional after restarting the swss. The warnings might be expected because the interfaces are removed and it would take several seconds to add them back in the middle of which lldp might try to send packet and throw this warning

I also see the same issue on the Arista 7060X6-16.

I can prime this failure if I run the test `l2/test_l2_configure.py` first. After that, any subsequent run of `lldp/test_lldp.py::test_lldp_neighbor_post_swss_reboot` will fail the loganalyzer check.

I am able to resolve the issue by cleaning up the cache after the `l2` test, I have a PR here
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/pull/21063

I am not sure if my fix resolves the issue on your platform. Perhaps this change can be limited to master for now?

After more test runs this log analyzer failure still occurs occasionally. I now think we should have it in 202505 and other relevant branches until flakiness is root caused.

EDIT:
one more note, to make it reliably run, there are 2 ways:
1. run `test_pretest.py` between l2 and lldp
2. wait for some time before running lldp
hi @yejianquan would you help to cherrypick to 202505? This fix flaky issue of test_lldp.

@ytzur1 could you please provide more details from when the regression started happening and what is the change in buildimage caused this?

Hi @vvolam,
We encountered an issue with it when the test failed and we got 'index out of range' error for the logger error msg.

You can see that in all previous places the used index is - 
reboot_cause_history_got[reboot_type_history_len - index - 1]

But if the reboot cause is not as expected and we enter the if condition - than the logger msg use a different index 
reboot_cause_history_got[reboot_type_history_len - index] **without (-1)**
and that raise an index error so I fixed it.

Hi @Abdul-Wahab-17, there is some issue in the test
1. Test will be skipped because of code below. It's because of `dut_port` is something like `dut_name|port_name`, which will never appear in `ptf_map` 
```
 if dut_port not in ptf_map:
 pytest.skip(
 f"no ptf mapping for DUT port {dut_port} in tbinfo; can't run traffic"
 )
```
2. You can't send packet from ptf to DUT as the PFC_ON/OFF will not be forwarded by leaf fanout

The DASH_ROUTE_TABLE links to TUNNEL1:
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/b59061628cfc019aaba50192a179c862f5dcdbd0/tests/dash/configs/privatelink_config.py#L135
But we are applying TUNNEL2 config and expecting Tunnel2 IPs in the return path:
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/b59061628cfc019aaba50192a179c862f5dcdbd0/tests/dash/test_trusted_vni.py#L76
https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/b59061628cfc019aaba50192a179c862f5dcdbd0/tests/dash/test_trusted_vni.py#L129

As per:
https://github.com/sonic-net/SONiC/blob/master/doc/dash/dash-sonic-hld.md#364-er-gw-bypass---private-link
The "trusted_vni" in the appliance field should contain the GRE key so that the packet from the PE to the DPU is not dropped
the key is changed to "trusted_vnis" in sonic-dash-api proto https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-dash-api/blob/f62792efae6a61fba8455acb89df1cfbb66d4257/proto/appliance.proto#L16 (of type ValueOrRange)

I’ve read this PR, and I have some concerns about lowering the appl_param_active_links_thr_high value. Reducing this threshold could potentially lead us back to the disjointed topology issue.

The current value is based on the fabric card detected at the time the code runs, which could lead to a race condition where the initialization of the fabric cards is delayed, resulting in a lower value than necessary. Additionally, the use of a constant value of 24 per fabriccards raises some concerns as well.

I would recommend that if specific systems (like certain Notika systems or some specific SKWs) are experiencing issues with appl_param_active_links_thr_high, we should target those systems directly for adjustments. We should limit these changes to only those specific ones, rather than applying them broadly across all systems. thank you 

@kenneth-arista @vmittal-msft @arlakshm

> I’ve read this PR, and I have some concerns about lowering the appl_param_active_links_thr_high value. Reducing this threshold could potentially lead us back to the disjointed topology issue.
>

Additionally, the use of a constant value of 24 per fabriccards raises some concerns as well.
> 
> I would recommend that if specific systems (like certain Notika systems or some specific SKWs) are experiencing issues with appl_param_active_links_thr_high, we should target those systems directly for adjustments. We should limit these changes to only those specific ones, rather than applying them broadly across all systems. thank you
> 
> @kenneth-arista @vmittal-msft @arlakshm

Hi @jfeng-arista, for more context as is written in #18183, existing values for `appl_param_active_links_thr_high` is currently appropriate for testbeds where all fabric card slots are populated, and no changes are needed there.

We are trying to tackle the case where not all fabric cards are populated in a lab device, in such a case, it's possible for `appl_param_active_links_thr_high` to be higher than the active fabric links, which affects the fabric cards and causes iBGP links not to come up.

Currently our workaround is already to manually reduce `appl_param_active_links_thr_high` for iBGP links to come up, which we are simply automating the process here. Could you propose any solutions for the race condition and constant value of 24 per fabriccards (This could probably be solved by directly getting the Operating links in `show fabric monitor capacity`)?

> > I’ve read this PR, and I have some concerns about lowering the appl_param_active_links_thr_high value. Reducing this threshold could potentially lead us back to the disjointed topology issue.
> > The current value is based on the fabric card detected at the time the code runs, which could lead to a race condition where the initialization of the fabric cards is delayed, resulting in a lower value than necessary. Additionally, the use of a constant value of 24 per fabriccards raises some concerns as well.
> > I would recommend that if specific systems (like certain Notika systems or some specific SKWs) are experiencing issues with appl_param_active_links_thr_high, we should target those systems directly for adjustments. We should limit these changes to only those specific ones, rather than applying them broadly across all systems. thank you
> > @kenneth-arista @vmittal-msft @arlakshm
> 
> Hi @jfeng-arista, for more context as is written in #18183, existing values for `appl_param_active_links_thr_high` is currently appropriate for testbeds where all fabric card slots are populated, and no changes are needed there.
> 
> We are trying to tackle the case where not all fabric cards are populated in a lab device, in such a case, it's possible for `appl_param_active_links_thr_high` to be higher than the active fabric links, which affects the fabric cards and causes iBGP links not to come up.
> 
> Currently our workaround is already to manually reduce `appl_param_active_links_thr_high` for iBGP links to come up, which we are simply automating the process here. Could you propose any solutions for the race condition and constant value of 24 per fabriccards (This could probably be solved by directly getting the Operating links in `show fabric monitor capacity`)?

Hi @Javier-Tan, Jie suggested that if these changes are needed for certain specific SKUs, please limit the change to only apply to these SKUs. The point of the high threshold is to only bring up the fabric connectivity between forwarding ASICs once sufficient links are present. For example, one fabric card is not likely to be sufficient to provide the necessary bandwidth for a chassis. However, with this change, the high threshold value would be overridden to allow such a system to come up. One suggestion is to tune the SOC property values according to the minimum number of fabric cards needed to guarantee sufficient redundancy and bandwidth. These values should be static and not touched during sonic-mgmt testing. Consequently, this PR would not be needed. However, if you insist to modify these settings on-the-fly, then limit these changes to SKUs in your lab that pose this problem. Let us know if you're encountering issues with Arista chassis in the lab.
Azure Pipelines successfully started running 1 pipeline(s).

@jfeng-arista @kenneth-arista we can have a discussion on this. But this is needed for us to allow lab testing of Qos/RDMA test suites on different chassis types since ours chassis are not fully populated and this feature is not allowing us to bring up fabric links if lower and it is not an issue with specific HWSKU. In production, we don't have this restriction as chassis is fully populated with fabric cards.
@Javier-Tan @arlakshm Can we make this change only applicable for lab devices and not production so we can catch any issue in production ?

> es since ours chassis are not fully populated and this feature is not allowing us to bring up fabric links if lower and it is not an issue with specific HWSKU. In production, we don't have this restriction as chassis is fully populated with fabric cards.

Sure, I can understand this. But still, I think this can be limited to specific SKUs ( like Nokia systems only ) if needed.

Here's a quick summary of the comments/discussions. There are a number of problems with this PR:
- The logic to check whether or not the system is fully populated is flawed as it relies on a hard-coded math formula to generate the number of fabric links, which does not reflect the diversity in hardware designs (e.g. `active_fabric_cards.stdout | int 2016 2017 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024 2025 parse_prs.py parse_reviews.py pr_dump.sh 24`)
- The production SOC property values are set assuming a fully populated system and guards against forwarding switch chips from joining the topology until sufficient fabric links are stable. This code breaks and circumvents this guard by arbitrarily setting the high threshold to available links. If there are genuine problems with fabric connectivity, this change may potentially mask it.

Acknowledging all the above comments, will continue to work on a solution everyone's happy with

```
112
112

AFTER DEPLOY-MG:

64
64
```
